I wasn't expecting a return to a classic formula. From the trailer, it was clear the game would diverge from the usual. Having completed 100% of the game and explored all five endings, I found its psychological core unmistakably Silent Hill.  You'll instantly recognize the seriesâ€™ essence: guilt, confusion, identity, trauma, and the slow descent into oneâ€™s own inner world. Whether or not it fits the traditional American town or earlier gameplay style, the spirit remains.

The story is much deeper and more complicated than it seems. It blends folktales and myths as context along with personal psychology in a way that only becomes clear after multiple playthroughs. The game is designed so that your first run is intentionally incomplete, confusing and disappointing because the character herself is lost, fragmented, and drowning in self-doubt. Only in NG+ runs does the narrative open up. Each ending reveals a different perspective on her identity, trauma, and relationships. The game provides fair instructions on how to unlock each at the main menu. By your fourth playthrough, the story finally clicks into place, and the emotional impact becomes much heavier.

As for the gameplay, itâ€™s definitely the most divisive part. Itâ€™s not a traditional Silent Hill combat, and it's not meant to be a pure action system. I don' t mind a souls-like, I think it reinforces the tension: youâ€™re fragile but capable, constantly overwhelmed and under pressure ... after all you're playing a teenage girl who fights society norms with a pipe.

The art design on the other hand is impeccable, it creates a haunting atmosphere infused with the decaying allure of spider lilies, symbolizing death and rebirth. The enemies you'll face are evocative symbols that reflect Hinako's perspective in a conservative society; hence, the enemy variety is limited. Each creature she encounters visually manifests her fears and embodies how her environment has shaped her psyche, deepening the overall impact of the game's aesthetic.

I realized that f stands for the musical term forte, which made sense why I don't like this particular OST as much as earlier entries in the series. The loud notes in the soundtrack, especially during enemy presence seem to emphasize the title's meaning. While it may not be to my liking, the music plays a crucial role on Hinako's desire for peace and quiet.

Iâ€™m going to defend this game, because I see a lot of people unanimously claiming itâ€™s â€œnot a very good Silent Hillâ€  without really giving it a fair try.

First, letâ€™s talk about the price: to actually finish the game, it takes around 12 to 14 hours on your first run. And if you want to reach the true ending  the one that gives you the full understanding of the storyâ€™s depth  youâ€™ll need to play it at least twice, with new cutscenes and different narrative stakes (just like in other Silent Hill games, by the way). So yes, I can understand the criticism about the price, because â‚¬80 is definitely excessive in general, no matter the game.

Then, Silent Hill f doesnâ€™t just copy the seriesâ€™ classic formula  it reinterprets it through a deeply introspective approach centered on Hinako.
Where the older titles confronted the player with guilt, shame, or denial, Silent Hill f explores identity fragility and social pressure  the forces that shape a personâ€™s psyche. The game doesnâ€™t just aim to scare you with monsters or disturbing environments, but rather to visually and symbolically express Hinakoâ€™s emotions, fears, and inner contradictions.

And thatâ€™s exactly where I think the game excels: it perfectly masters its atmosphere. Everything in it is designed to be replayed  a single playthrough isnâ€™t enough to grasp all its nuances. Only by starting over, by looking differently, do you start to perceive the coherence behind the symbols, the echoes between events, and what they truly reveal about the character.

If youâ€™re familiar with RyÅ«kishi07â€™s work, youâ€™ll clearly see where heâ€™s taking us. In fact, I think itâ€™s sometimes a good thing not to be constantly guided through a story  it allows you to appreciate it on a deeper level. And thatâ€™s exactly what RyÅ«kishi07 achieves here.

Lastly, let me repeat it: Silent Hill is not just a town  itâ€™s a concept.
Itâ€™s an idea, a psychological experience where each story and each protagonist becomes a mirror of human suffering. And in that sense, I donâ€™t see how Silent Hill f is any less of a Silent Hill than the others. Sure, Kojima isnâ€™t behind it, but this game explores  perhaps even more deeply  the psychological and symbolic dimensions that have defined the series from the very beginning.

Many people are quick to judge the surface  the pacing, the art direction, or the narrative structure  but Silent Hill f is above all about the psychology of its main character.
Itâ€™s not a story that reveals itself easily; it asks the player to engage, to think, to interpret. Itâ€™s a work that refuses to explain everything, choosing to suggest rather than show. And thatâ€™s precisely what makes it so rich.

In my opinion, thatâ€™s where some players miss the point. Hinakoâ€™s depth as a character isnâ€™t immediately obvious  it slowly reveals itself through details, silences, and symbols. You need to take the time to dive in, replay, and observe to fully understand what the game is saying about her  and, ultimately, about the human condition itself.

Silent Hil F is a bizarre case where Steam reviews would benefit from a â€œMixed Feelingsâ€ verdict. Since Steam lacks nuance I will keep this short: if you are a newcomer to the franchise, you will likely enjoy this. If you are a veteran, this will be the most divisive title since Silent Hill 4. 

Silent Hill F takes the series in a wildly new direction. It abandons the familiar discomfort of urban American in exchange for ShÅwa era Japan. Due to it's remote setting, firearms are omitted and replaced with melee weapons. 

To address the elephant in the room, Silent Hill F plays like a soulslike. While that term has been beaten to death more often than the mannequins in Silent Hill 2, all the hallmarks of the design philosophy are there. Attacks consume stamina and have long animations that are hard to cancel. Dodging is your primary defensive method. Enemies have very brief periods where you can hit them with a devastating counter. 

Unfortunately, the developers seem to learned all the wrong lessons as well. Your weapons bounce off walls, which is incredibly frustrating due to the gameâ€™s frequent enclosed levels. Breaking a weapon causes a nonsensical 1.5 second stun where monsters are free to hit you. Enemies repeatedly use heavily delayed attacks with absurd levels of tracking. It seems that the devs forgot that anger and frustration is an emotion that can easily overpower fear, which is a fatal issue: the game is not scary and the combat is to blame. 

That being said, there are positives. The vocal performances are spectacular, especially Konatsu Kanoâ€™s labored performance as Hinako Shimizu. Visuals are fantastic and the mystery of Ebisugaoka is wrapped in a competent narrative penned by Ryukishi07. The issue is you have to go through a Nier-like experience to grasp the full story, and many players will likely be put off by the clunky parts of the game to warrant 4 full playthroughs. To Silent Hill veterans who have ample amounts of patience and tolerance for frustration, this title is for you.

I'm still fairly new to the Silent Hill Franchise, with only playing the SH2 remake. Nevertheless, I understand when a game is not perfect or even flawed, despite the horror genre being one of my favs.
 
Silent Hill f is a great game that experiments with a new direction compared to previous games in the franchise. Yes, some things are well implemented, while others are not so great. If you're looking for a compelling and rich narrative, then this game has you covered. In addition, the game's visuals capture a beautiful, yet creepy setting. One interesting thing that I enjoyed a lot was how further playthroughs (new game plus) reveal new cutscenes/or dialogue that add more to the story. Also, just reading the notes along the way kept me hooked, and I was eager to put things together. Furthermore, resource management and player progression are very satisfying/rewarding. Lastly, there are many good puzzles to solve, and playing on the higher difficulties really tests you at times until you realize the solution.

Now, onto some negatives. The combat is the most controversial. There are times I liked it and others I didn't. The main issue is that it sometimes feels responsive and other times does not. In general, if you don't like souls-like combat, then I warn you before buying, since this game utilizes the combat for the majority of the game. Another big negative is the visual bugs and brief stutters you will experience when playing. Of course, it definitely is immersion-breaking, but it wasn't a big mood killer for me. On the other hand, experiencing stutters in higher difficulties can be annoying to navigate. The game generally ran a stable framerate for me, apart from a few sections of the game. If performance is a deal-breaker for you, I recommend looking for optimization videos or guides on Steam.

Overall, I enjoyed playing this game and just kept wanting to discover more about the characters/or story.  I recommend this game to those who just want new SH content or horror fans, despite its flaws.

Silent Hill F takes place in the 90s and explores a young girl named Shimizu Hinako who struggles to find herself in a losing situation where she has to be married off to a rich man. Since this game takes place during that time, there will be traditional aspects of how a woman and how a man should be like. While I think that is pretty obvious from the first run and the tragic ending Hinako ends herself up in, it doesn't explain everything else that's going on in her life that explains the story in a better picture. 

You can tell that Hinako is a very lost girl throughout the game and doesn't have a clear mind about herself, or the future of marrying off to a man. All of that pressure building up by the needs of having to meet up to those expectations from her parents is very, very stressful and it shows from how she has viewed it and experienced it â€” based from her parents relationship together and how they have behaved or acted towards her. While she is very clear about what she wants for herself and what happiness is and means to her, she ends up finding herself not being able to do what she exactly wants. You may understand that she's very determined about not wanting to marry off to that man but the whole question is why she doesn't want that? That's where I believe if you want to understand the whole reason behind that is to continue the game on New Game+ and get the other endings. 

There is other side characters that I haven't mentioned above and I feel like they are very much put off aside because this game mainly focuses on the main character Hinako, where her friends do play a small role into how Hinako might feel about herself or why she may act the way she does. As Shu, Rinko and Sakuko being her 3 main friends, Shu is the only guy who I think has a bigger story to him than what the game is trying to tell you. Other than knowing that he's the one who's been making the capsules for Hinako, you don't get to read any notes from him that you could of found within the game other than reading about him through Hinako's journal, or throughout some of the cutscenes. Besides him, there's also a lot of things going on about the man himself, Kotoyuki Tsuneki, who wants to marry himself to Hinako. You won't be able to understand him fully either, unless you reach the last "true" ending while reading more notes about him on the way there.

As I think by going through the game multiple times, it can be repeating for some people, but I believe people will miss out on the whole story of the game and what it's trying to tell you if you leave it off at the first ending. It's understandable if you were bothered about the games' combat system, because I myself did feel somewhat frustrated with it sometimes when facing off against one or multiple enemies at once. My main problem with it was when I had to face off against the last main bosses at the endings where learning their attacks took time to get used to, while some of their attacks felt impossible to dodge no matter how much distance I had and if I dodged too early or too late.

I deeply and heavily relate to Hinako and find myself within her in some ways which most people probably won't be able to relate to. Either because of her age, her gender, or the whole aspect where she is stuck with having to marry. Other than that, she does have a lot of trauma and finds herself as two different people, where one is hiding within her and I find myself having the same kind of feelings and flaws as she does. Additionally, the way most of her friends seems to act towards her can seem to be pretty toxic on the outside, but after playing the whole game, I can understand why they acted the way they did.

The game is definitely worth the price if you decide to do all of the endings. Plus maybe by doing all of the achievements as well, which weren't as complicated as I thought they would be. If you do think of buying this game and not doing all of the endings, I would recommend waiting for the game to go on sale.

The title of the newest game in the series might stand for a number of things, and they all make sense once you go through the story.

Set in a little japanese village during the 60s, the game stars the young Hinako who soon inexplicably finds herself in a town devoid of life, full of monsters and gradually more and more enveloped by strange flowers. Her only anchor being her friends who along with herself are dragged in these strange happenings. Happenings that become stranger and stranger indeed, as they unfold in an almost oneiric way, in true, old school Silent Hill fashion.

SHf deals with the struggles of a teenager whose life is about to change drastically, if typically for the time, but in a direction that's completely opposite to her own beliefs and aspirations, and how such a thing is incredibly damaging and shocking to her persona. A parable about how lack of choice and freedom can violently impact the psyche of an individual; akin to discarding your old beloved self and becoming someone else entirely. As shocking as losing a limb, if you will.

As one would expect, SHf plays heavily on the psychological aspect of horror, where the protagonist's mind and her circumstances are more than enough capable to inflict terror and gore than actual monstrous creatures. But where also old gods, customs and folklore end up meddling with such fragile individuals.

Even by not being set in the town of Silent Hill itself, f's writer Ryukishi07 shows he understand what he's working with. And in doing so, he and NeoBards created a new Silent Hill game that keeps most of its core aspects while also attaining its own identity. In other words, if I'm allowed some sass, f did its own thing instead of trying to ape beloved Silent Hill 2 as other developers might or might have not attempted to do in the past.

Now, f is not devoid of issues. Combat is initially fairly strict and at times clunky and not the most responsive. The main areas are perhaps not as complex or extensive as one might have been expecting to in relation to the main games in the series, and enemy variety ends up being perhaps a bit lacking in the latter half of the game, especially considering the amount of combat the player has to engage with.

Your mileage might vary, but personally I did not find these aspects to be much of a detriment to the whole experience.

Even with it being a spin off of sorts (with the devs calling it a "gaiden" title) Silent Hill f is the strongest game in the series since the first three entries, and more generally good news for the SH franchise. The series is back, is doing well after an initial bumpy start (*cough* Ascension *cough*), and it looks like it's here to stay according to sales and reception. Well done Konami, well done.

A psychological survival horror game that puts you in the shoes of Shimizu Hinako. As these things go you don't get to spend much time with her and her friends before it all goes to hell. The game is gorgeous visually, it really makes good use of the foggy aesthetic and rural japanese setting, and this plus the game's soundscape make for an excellent horror atmosphere that keeps you hooked from start to finish. Without revealing too much about the story it's an interesting dive into Hinako's past trauma and a mystery to be pieced together, as you'll eventually realise things may not be what they seem. It makes for a really engaging narrative.

In terms of gameplay outside the quieter moments of exploration you have the puzzles and combat you might expect. The combat is entirely melee, with a familiar setup for a third person brawler: light attack, heavy attack, dodge, counter and some special attacks. It can be a bit janky but is also a big step up from the survival horror games of before (not a high bar admittedly). It has nice impactful hits, can be tense (especially above Story difficulty) but also lacks enemy variety. Its not a bad game, its also not the worst Silent Hill game either, its actually pretty solid in both of those categories! The game has a good story and tells it in a very Silent hill Fashion. You see Hinako from the start of the game confused as to what is happening and slowly loose her sanity while you progress in your journey. Notes are scattered through the town that you can find if you are a curious explorer that dive deeper into the personalities of both Hinako and other characters. The combat is actually pretty ok too and I would say an improvement from the previous entries but... as you read earlier, I think they should of stuck with a different design for it or tweaked certain aspects about it. I do commend them however for trying to make it more engaging and more fun as the combat for the games were always one of the biggest flaws in the franchise since it often was either very repetitive or frustrating (in hind sigh its kind of funny because in this game it still is on many occasions).

So lets get into it, whats wrong with the combat? Well, it feels tedious, and at times I felt like it did not work properly. For starters, you have a Stamina Bar, which shouldn't be a big deal but... the game quite literally tells you that Hinako was in track and field and was a very good runner, so why the hell do we even have a stamina bar in the first place if she was already established as a person with good dexterity. On top of having a stamina bar they added Weapon durability, which would make sense if this was a survival horror but they are very clearly leaning more towards an action base souls-like combat. They also added a sanity bar which depletes if you do "focus" attacks or get hit by monsters which I guess plays into the psychological horror aspect. All of these different mechanics make it feel like Konami was not sure what direction they wanted to take the game at first so they tried their best to balance them all to make them work together. It's as if they were playing a constant game of tug of war between making it an action horror or a psychological Horror but also a survival horror. Ultimately what Konami created was a very tedious Horror Souls-like where you have to worry about too many things but nothing at the same time. 

See the problem is that in reality, none of it really matters. Weapons Break? The game places tons of weapons throughout the town for you to collect or swap out (you can only carry 3) in case one of them is about to break or you like the other one better because depending on the weapon you use, they do different damage and act differently. If that's not enough the game also places a ton of tool-kits for you to find if you are an explorer like myself that allows you to repair a weapon a good amount. These two factors make weapon durability completely obsolete, and the point is driven more to home when you step into the "other" world called Dark Shrine where they give you 2 weapons types (one light and one medium) that don't break at all.

The Stamina bar made combats frustrating as if you run out of stamina, you are basically SOL, and you use stamina for both swinging your pipe and dodges because of course this game has a dodge! its a Horror souls-like after all! And yes, it also has a Parry Window for enemies which by the way, doesn't always work? or shows you when it happens and also a perfect dodge which was basically useless as attacking after a dodge can still make you miss and did not stagger enemies most times. I don't have a problem that enemies don't always do an attack you can parry because if that's all they did the game would not be very engaging and you would sit around waiting for the visual queue to press the button at the right time (which I did do in a lot of my encounters so it was still an issue). The problem Lies in the Monsters animations for their regular attacks as the game gives you almost no warning that they will be hitting you making it almost impossible to predict or react fast enough.

The sanity Bar I do not even know what the point of it was as it doesn't make you go crazy or lose health, it was purely just used for focused attacks which I did not even do at all as your regular heavy and light attacks do enough damage. I thought sanity would play more towards other aspects of the game but in reality it does not.

There is also Inventory Management which is fine but again, it doesn't seem like they were going for a Survival Horror and leaned more towards an Action horror so whats the point? it also didn't affect you much as most items were used to trade for a currency to upgrade your characters base stats.

All of these issues can be easily fixed as well if they would of just stuck to one thing instead of trying to add as many things as possible to make it engaging. Weapons don't need durability at all, just let me carry 2 different weapons and lay different types throughout the map I can swap with depending on what my play style preference is. Take away the Stamina bar, its not necessary and makes combat more annoying, I often just ignored enemies because of it and dreaded fighting others. Make my sanity bar something I actually need to worry about, its a psychological horror game and sanity was just used to do better attacks... why not make me see things that are not there or make healing items less effective. [b]Maybe always show when you can do a parry attack if you're going to include it, I had to guess for certain encounters and other times Hinako didn't even parry even though I pressed the button exactly when the animation played[/b]

I also had a problem with the story around 3/4th of the way into the game, as it stopped being very Psychological horror and felt like it was getting very Resident Evil. It does "explain" towards the end as to why but it still felt like it was a bit too ridiculous. There is usually a balance to be stricken when creating this type of horror game and the scale definitely tipped towards one side more at a certain point.

What makes things worse is that, while you can avoid most enemies early on to save resources (or your patience), the final act traps you in a series of arenas filled with the same enemy types over and over. The frustration piles up fast, and so does the urge to just finish the game and be done with it. Itâ€™s largely because of this repetitive and exhausting final act that I wonâ€™t replay the game, though the other endings I watched on YouTube do offer a deeper understanding of the story and Hinakoâ€™s â€œchoices.â€ Standard enemies are very few and become stale almost immediately. Outside of combat, though, the experience is much better. Exploration is engaging (even if interactions are minimal), and the puzzles range from simple to surprisingly intricate. Nothing groundbreaking, but the exploration + puzzle loop works far better than the forced arena combat. Toward the end, the balance is clearly lost, as if the game were stretched out artificially.

There is a lot to be said and discussed about how Silent Hill f measures up to other games of the franchise. More specifically, how it measures up to the original four numbered games. A huge bar, to be sure; one that requires more than simply being "good" or "bad". There is an underlying texture to those, an uncanniness. They are more than the sum of their parts, even if the parts are made of shining gold: the Yamaoka OST, the Ito design, the purpose behind it all. It might be lightning in a bottle.

So, is Silent Hill f a good Silent Hill game? In my opinion, very much so.

Ironically, I started this review with the exact same comparison I will now suggest you to avoid. Silent Hill f is different. Not just for the Japanese setting, no: I don't think it's trying to be like the Team Silent endeavours, at least not completely. It is less oppressive, less decayed, definitely less rusty. It abandons the (excellent) established aesthetic for something different, something more solemn at times. The horror in f feels deeply rooted in tradition, in the darker underlying aspects of everyday life, or in old, worn-out relationships. There is no strange town with transient, unfamiliar characters anymore. Here, you are at home, with friends and family. What is worse? As I said, it is a different type of horror, but still very effective. It feels more on the nose; less ambiguous, less mysterious, a bit more shallow, perhaps, but still Silent Hill where it matters.

Combat feels great, and it is very much the bread and butter of this game, if a bit too prevalent. It's a stamina-managing scrap where you're constantly looking out for opening and counter opportunities and one mistake will probably have you expending a health item or two. It might not sound fun, but it is: you'll familiarize yourself with movesets, both enemy-wise and weapon-wise. From there, it's the joy of execution. Thankfully, the weapon durability gauge had me more wondering if my pipe could last another fight than actively breaking mid combat, and while there is unfortunately not much enemy variety, it also means you can more readily tell how a fight is gonna go.

It is a great horror game, really; and while a conversation can definitely be had about story implications and all the ways it deviates from the series old ways, I will say it's assuredly worth a playthrough.

There are connections, but they're mostly Easter eggs. Which is nothing that Silent Hill hasn't done before, as they've had multiple self-contained stories before. SH4, for example, doesn't take place in the actual town. The story was incredible on so many levels, and I love the classic Silent Hill move of having to play through the game a couple of times to get all of the endings. I especially loved that the game changed in subtle ways after reaching each respective ending.

The combat was frustrating at first, but I've gotten so used to it now that it doesn't bother me. One of the things that makes Silent Hill what it is is the atmosphere in the game. That's one thing that SH never gets wrong, and this game is no different. It also follows along with the SH trend of the monsters being so heavily steeped in the main character's trauma and psyche, another thing that only SH can pull off quite so well. Also, like other SH games before it, it has bred an absolutely astounding amount of conversation about the game, what each monster means, and how deeply that fear can go. 

All in all, I'd say it's an amazing game. Well worth the repeat plays if you can get used to the combat system. I think this is the first game I'll go out of my way to actually try to 100% in achievements.

As someone who thoroughly enjoyed Silent Hill 2's recent release, I was excited for Silent Hill F. Unfortunately, while the game has some strong elements, it falls short in execution across almost every aspect.

My issues began before starting. Silent Hill F only offers two difficulty options: "Story" and "Hard." The absence of a "Normal" difficulty (usually the developer's intended experience) forced me into choosing between "very easy" or "very difficult."

I chose Hard, assuming it would be equivalent to Normal, since "Story" usually offers little to no challenge. This was a mistake that negatively impacted my entire playthrough.

[h2]Combat - The Game's Biggest Problem[/h2]

Combat is significantly more prominent than in Silent Hill 2, which wouldn't be an issue if well-executed. Unfortunately, the combat system is fundamentally flawed.

Enemies have erratic, random attack patterns. While some attacks are telegraphed with parry indicators, many come without warning and cannot be parried. This punishes you for engaging with the mechanics the game teaches you.

You are able to "focus" to slow down enemies when they're about to attack... But only if the attack can be parried, which makes it unreliable.

The optimal strategy becomes staying at range, darting in for quick hits, then retreating. Staying close often results in unavoidable damage, especially against multiple enemies.

On Hard, you die in about two hits while enemies absorb massive amounts of damage. Deaths rarely feel like learning experiences; instead, they feel arbitrary because many attacks aren't properly telegraphed.

The game juggles too many systems:
- Health
- Stamina (shared between dodging, attacking, and blocking)
- Sanity (used for focus attacks and "focusing")
- Weapon durability
- An excessive variety of items

While this complexity works in some games, here it feels like unnecessary padding. The stamina system in particular is frustrating.  You can only dodge twice before running out, preventing you from attacking. It's manageable against single enemies but the game throws multiple at you constantly, forcing repeated dodges. You'll want to run around instead but the game blocks paths, forcing you into small arenas.

Weapons break frequently. You can repair them but you'll usually find enough lying around for it not to matter. Several weapon types are functionally identical. I found it annoying to leave weapons behind when full, only to run out later. Interestingly, in certain sections, weapons don't have durability and combat is noticeably more enjoyable, making the return to durability feel worse.

[h2]Item Management - Unnecessarily Complicated[/h2]

Silent Hill 2 had a simple healing system: small heals and large heals, each assigned to a button. Silent Hill F unnecessarily complicates this.

You have a shortcut wheel with 8 slots, but the game has more than 8 item types you'll need. This means constantly pausing to swap items. Many items serve similar purposes (healing, restoring sanity/stamina), and some can be sold for omamori charms. Deciding between selling or keeping resources is great, but the constant menu navigation becomes tedious.

This happens frequently since items are sparse. You'll use a healing item, then find a different one you just removed from shortcuts.

There's no good reason to have more item types than shortcut slots, especially when multiple items do the same thing.

[h2]Enemy Variety or lack thereof[/h2]

The game features few enemy types (some nearly identical), yet combat dominates gameplay. Unlike Silent Hill 2, where enemies appeared sparingly in specific environments, Silent Hill F constantly throws the same few at you.

Some are particularly annoying, like those spraying goo everywhere, forcing you to wait before attacking. When you spend this much time staring at enemies, they really aren't as scary...

Near the end, it becomes absurdly enemy-heavy. Two steps, fight enemies for 15 minutes, two more steps, more enemies. At the end, it was so ridiculous it made me laugh. It just felt generally very dirsruptive.

[h2]Boss Fights[/h2]

Ironically, I enjoyed boss fights significantly more than regular combat. Unclear telegraphing largely disappears, and attacks are clear and learnable. The first boss felt fair and satisfying. I could predict when to dodge and parry, and it was rewarding to pull off.

However, I felt like bosses were poorly tuned on hard. Some timing windows feel unnecessarily strict (like running toward one boss; Start 1 sec too late and you never make it). Fights are also far too long. After learning patterns perfectly and taking no damage, I'd still chip away at health forever. This isn't difficult, just tedious.

[h2]Visuals and Atmosphere[/h2]

The game looks genuinely beautiful. The Japan setting is well-realized, character models are detailed, and environments are visually striking. However, I was disappointed at the lack of diversity. There were only 2 or 3 distinct environments and they felt somewhat empty.

[h2]Story and Characters[/h2]

The story feels mysterious and has disturbing scenes and creative moments. But I found the characters uninteresting. NPCs appear briefly, act as if you're traveling together, then inexplicably disappear throughout the whole game.

My biggest disappointment is how on-the-nose the narrative becomes. Silent Hill 2 left room for interpretation and symbolism. Silent Hill F initially seems deeper, but by the end explicitly tells you what everything means. Instead of respecting your intelligence and letting you piece things together, it simply explains its themes outright.

[h2]Puzzles[/h2]

The puzzles are okay. They were usually creative ones and had nice horror flair.

However, some were frustrating, unintuitive or outright misleading (like telling you to find a smiling doll when the right one isn't smiling). I had to look up solutions for several and sometimes didn't even understand them.

Some puzzles are so cryptic you wonder if you're a genius or just lucky when you solve them.

One near the end made you fight 2 tough enemies every mistake, with no escape or resources. I looked it up after wasting everything. The solution was extremely subtle with no hints.

[h2]Multiple Endings and Replayability[/h2]

To get the true ending, you must complete the game multiple times. While I appreciate replays being different, I strongly dislike being [i]forced[/i] to replay. Silent Hill F's tedious combat killed any desire. I started a second playthrough and quickly stopped.

Gating content behind multiple runs feels like artificial padding, especially when playthroughs are mostly identical. It feels deliberate given how short the game is. Having different ending is fine... But I didn't feel like playing through it again immediately just to see the real conclusion.

[h2]A Note on Criticism[/h2]

Midway through, I saw people were complaining the protagonist is female or that the game addresses women's issues. This is absurdly stupid, especially when there are legitimate issues... The protagonist's gender isn't one of them.

[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]

I'm happy Konami is making single-player games again and we're getting new Silent Hill content. The game has the right pieces: good visuals, an interesting setting, decent puzzles, engaging boss fights. But execution is mediocre across the board.

Would Story difficulty have been better? Possibly. Though eliminating some combat frustrations probably wouldn't fix everything else. The game is also quite short, making the $90+ price tag hard to justify.

If you're craving modern Silent Hill, this is your only option. But I'd strongly recommend playing the Silent Hill 2 remake instead, or waiting on a huge discount.

      To start on a good note, I love the new setting and I wanted to see something like this for a long time, ever since Siren. The enemies kill you in two hits, and there is like 50 of them around the corner, and they respawn every time you die or use the "bonfire".      And then comes the quick use UI, which is kinda fine on keyboard, I guess (except that in action packed souls-like combat you have to use the 1-8 buttons to heal), but on controller I have to press like 3 buttons, to navigate a menu, just to start the healing action which isn't even instant, while I am "supposedly" being attacked by an enemy that can one shot me with low health.

      In the end, the game is really being held back by some poor design choices that are too deeply rooted to be fixed without building them from the ground up. Silent Hill was never known for a good combat system and this one will not change that, but it does offer a new original story in the Silent Hill franchise and a new setting, and that is awesome. 
      Is it worth playing? If you are ready to withstand the jankiness of the "souls-like" combat and are ready to play through the game multiple times to get the full story - yes. + Despite the change of scenery, the SH aesthetic is alive and well in the remote mountain village of Ebisugaoka, complete with Akira Yamaoka bringing a wholly new yet still distinctly Silent Hill soundscape. Moody and utterly abandoned streets convey that desolation essential for fostering an introspective dread in the player, whilst also making for worryingly tight confines to fight for your life within. + Graphics are gorgeous and efficient. I can't recall a single visual bug or performance hiccup. The characters are incredibly expressive despite their comparatively muted and closely guarded personalities, you still are able to understand what they are feeling.

This is anchored in the decision to make your painfully finite stamina the lifeline Hinako depends upon, and as it rapidly depletes, you're left wide open, forced to rely on footsies to evade attackers (to borrow  fighting game parlance) 

The twist is that if you perform a perfectly timed dodge you not only clear the danger but get all your stamina back. Similar to Bloodborne's feature where you can regain lost health with immediate retaliation, this design choice was clearly to push the player to embrace the fear in deliberately rolling into the attacks of your tormentors so you can maintain pressure in combat.

+/-  Puzzles are extremely hit-or-miss, ranging from blatantly-not-a-puzzle stuff akin to Doom's "find the blue key-card for the blue door" to so deviously nuanced that most folks complain about having to brute force it. I'M LOOKING AT YOU, CORN FIELD. More than that, they're repetitious- puzzle difficulty here simply means tacking on extra reiterations of the same puzzle, ranging from merely tedious to flat out exhausting. I'M LOOKING AT YOU, CORN FIELD. 

+/-  Pointless trigger warnings really oversell the harshness of the horror and the game's themes. Despite the heaps of creeping, rusty meat, it's not that graphic nor is it particularly upsetting- not in any visceral fashion, at least. The themes touched upon on are real and heavy, but it also lacks the scope or ability to delve into those topics... Only allude to it. 

There's one, theoretical exception: 
Ryukishi07 loves torture porn, after all... I still argue it pulls it's punches because it's:
1) mostly off-screen 
2) The victim in question doesn't react at all like a human, so it's just odd, not visceral. You can argue it's symbolic, and it is- but I still think that's a flimsy get-out. I watched Dagon (2001), dammit- this version is baby-mode!

I'm not being edgy, either- I'm queasy AF if anything... But it lacks conviction. It doesn't commit to portraying this as horrendous as it should be, despite supposedly being a pivotal moment meant to drive home the story's message. 

Why do it, then? Here's why:  "Quick, we need a shocking talking point!"

Horror is subjective, granted, so I'm not putting too much stock in this as far as objective criticisms. Just know that the game talks up a big forewarning in one hand and then pulls all it's punches with the other.




CONS:
------------------------------------------------

- Remember the combat system being good for duels? Violent Kill F runs out of ideas for escalation at the 2/3rds mark, gives up, and starts hurling clown cars full of monsters at you. You can't just run away, either- It's officially a brawler now.  You HAVE to kill all the monsters to progress, magic invisible walls and all.

It's a bad brawler, too. The variety of enemies is measly, so you will fight the same stupid 5 or 6 monsters dozens upon dozens upon dozens of times. They try to trick you by slapping flowers and jam on them in later levels, but it's just the same dolls you've been braining from the start.

You'll fight them almost exclusively in cramped corridors. Your main weapon is a nagitana, so your main charge attack used for tackling multiple enemies will just catch on said corridor walls and cancel out, leaving you open for every whiff punish imaginable. It's trying to emphasize spacing, but it fails. 

AND THEN they introduce the pregnant tanky Damage-Sponges that constantly crap out new monsters and clog the combat arena with fatass, And then copypaste them ad infinitum. They are simply and truly the worst.

- Weapon durability. Fuck off. 

- Instead of making one really good, condensed narrative where you understand what's happening start to finish, they decided to chop it up into a million breadcrumb story-beats spread out over 4 or 5 separate NG+ playthroughs. Playing once is already a chore thanks to the preggerpillars, and the first time around it gives you -nothing- to work with besides cryptic dialogue and constant, aggravating vagaries.

If you want any closure, you must endure this lukewarm brawler another 4 or 5 times... It sacrifices an otherwise strong story in the name of a gimmick, meant to pad out the engagement statistics.

- Instead of focusing on one or two subjects, it tries to juggle 4: 

1) The trials of being a woman in the 60s when all of culture was just one giant drunk dad.
2) Hinako's dysfunctional-ass family.
3) High school girls are the most vicious apex predators to walk the earth.
4) Yokai space opera (Kabuki?).

None of it is bad in abstract, but it's incredibly unfocused in it's execution. 




TL;DR:
---------------------------------------------------

It's better for a flawed game to start off weak and end strong. Unfortunately, Violent Kill F pulls the inverse.  It's by no means "bad" or "awful"- it actually does a lot of things very well- but that just makes the overall execution all the more frustrating. It mismanages a lot and asks far too much of the player for what it gives in return.

 At 70$ admission and another 40+ hours play time for the full narrative experience as intended, I just can't recommend it- not at this price. Having said all that, it's still much better than all the western developed SH titles (Is BlooberTeam western?)- if that's the only criteria your choice hinges upon, then go for it. 

Otherwise, I -strongly- urge you to wait until a sale much later down the line.

This is offset by the fact that, if you want to see the full story apart from the endings, you have to play it at least 3 times. But even with that in mind, it's only a maximum of 30 hours to see all important endings. But why do people quit the game after 8-15 hours if the game is at most 30? Because there are many issues with this game. Ignore all those that say that the game sucks because it is "woke", the game could have been the most antiwoke media in existence and it still would have sucked ass.

Being (suppossedly) a psychological horror game like SH2R, it is quite striking that the game is not scary at all. While the story overall is good, it touches a lot of themes about the life in Japan 70 years ago, especially from the perspective of women. The gameplay is even worse. Remember how clunky old school horror games were? Those were controlling the main character felt like driving a car? Well you'll wish those controls were back. The devs suppossedly got inspiration from Dark Souls (how original) and implemented a half-assed imitation of them. The combat has way too many different mechanics and combat requires you to "git gud" dark souls style. But here's the thing... To note: I beat the game once, then read up on the game's other/'true' endings. I had the combat difficulty set on [b]story[/b], the puzzles difficulty set on [b]hard[/b].

- [b]OST/Sound design:[/b] excellent!
- [b]Art direction:[/b] very good, though some designs left me puzzled (because of the way the story largely fails to integrate, or weave, its supernatural and more psychological aspects together).
- [b]Combat:[/b] hot flaming garbage! I cannot stress how much I loathed the combat, and I can't imagine what it must be like on hard, omg. The very fact this is an action horror game, not a survival horror game, was also definitely not to my personal preference and initial expectations.

- [b]Story:[/b] okay, so, on its own, and if only taking the first ending into account, I'd say it was... decent. I'm really not a fan of the [spoiler]"it was all a dream/psychosis"[/spoiler] formula as a general rule, but this iteration of it was alright (I've seen better, I've definitely seen worse) â€“ most of the symbolism pertaining to the non-supernatural aspect of the story made sense to me. That being said, if taking the story's subsequent endings into account, it becomes mediocre-to-bad in my book. The supernatural elements feel uninspired, and again don't actually mesh well, in my opinion, with the more mundane and psychological aspects of the plot. I'm left frustrated as a mythology nerd and fantasy fan with something that has [i]no real taste[/i], and I'm frustrated more generally as a good storytelling fan with something that doesn't feel committed enough to its psychological premise. Ironically, [spoiler]just like Hinako herself[/spoiler], the story's different parts suffer from a lack of organic integration. Then, well... this isn't really a Silent Hill game, is it? As such, it was also very disappointing. Finally, the very fact the story's full scope is locked behind not one, but multiple additional playthroughs p*sses me off to no end. It is a storytelling design philosophy I hate with a burning passion, be it in gaming, cinema or literature!

- [b]Theming:[/b] and so yeah, the theming was... okay. For me, it was all rather 'beginner' type stuff, that felt [b]too superficial[/b] in terms of content (with, again, wasted potential with regards to the mythological stuff), and [b]too convoluted[/b] in terms of narrative execution. I appreciate a male writer trying here, but the thing is I can tell it was done by a male writer, [b][i]trying[/i][/b], which just betrays an issue with the actual writing itself (i.e.: I've seen male authors write about gynocentric issues, or do "feminist" theming, so much better). [b]Silent Hill f[/b] almost feels like '[i]Man Bad Horror[/i]', which isn't the worst it could've been by any means, but still. Heart largely in the right place, but over-compensating, or rather 'over-showing' too much, is the gist of it.

- [b]Emotional engagement:[/b] there was next-to-none for me, whereas Silent Hill 2R made me cry (even triggered me) in places. [spoiler]Angela's story, and James', were infinitely more resonating to me, as a victim of past CSA and emotional abuse, than anything that happens in Silent Hill f, for instance.[/spoiler]
- [b]Horror factor:[/b] good overall, especially in the most Silent Hill-esque sections, but the over-reliance on combat-related jump scares really p*ssed me off after a while.

[b]Conclusion:[/b] I can't say I regret playing it, as such, but I would absolutely not recommend anyone buy this game at full price. My final rating? Right now, it's still kinda bouncing [b]between a 4.5 and 6/10[/b] â€“ because of all those different endings and how I feel they impact the quality of the story as a whole.

I'd give it a rating that's between "good" and "bad" if there was. Unfortunately, my overall experience is leaning towards giving it a bad review. TLDR at the bottom.

[h2]OPTIMIZATION/PERFORMANCE:[/h2]
This has been the worst performance I have ever seen in a game. SH2R performed great on my machine, both game uses the same engine, yet SHf is just outrageous. I have to download other person's ".ini" configuration file to optimize the game just to make it even playable. There are moments where the game just suddenly drops to 5-10 fps, and the only way to fix it is to return to the title screen and load it again.

[h2]VISUALS:[/h2]
Hands down, SHf visuals are superb. Eerie and unsettling atmosphere. Monster design is also great. Nothing bad I could say about SHf's visuals.

[h2]GAMEPLAY:[/h2]
This is the first time an area has felt tedious on my first playthrough; normally that only happens on the second. [spoiler]Parts where Hinako goes to "the underworld," felt very tiring and unscary in later stages. These are the parts that makes you say "Just get this over with." Where further exploration of these parts only rewards you with boring items, and a little bit of lore. [/spoiler]

Puzzles are also boring even on "Hard" difficulty. Most of them boil down to "find 3 items, insert them, proceed." or "go here, flip a switch, go back, flip it again, then go back again." Some puzzles are great and interesting, but the problem is, there's not much of them. [spoiler] The only puzzles that I found interesting were the locker and box in the school, and the scarecrow. [/spoiler] 

Combat could be better. You can find more weapons if you explore, but youâ€™ll usually ignore them if all of your equipped weapons are still in good condition. The major problem is that, weapon degredation is so fast that you would rather run from the enemy than to fight it. Otherwise, you might face a strong enemy later with a nearly broken weapon. It only takes 4 enemies, maybe even less, to fully destroy your weapon because of how tanky they are, and you encounter one almost every 5 minutes, and at times, even 3 of them at once. 

Facing an enemy also felt very tedious. Countering them is fun, but you only get few opportunities to do so. The counter indicator is very hard to see, if not, super quick. Adding to that, enemy attack patterns are not telegraphed very well for you to know what the enemy is going to do. Some attacks are slow, then some would be instant. Using focus mode or maintaining your distance is mostly the strategy, and that felt very 'cheesy'. 

Enemy grab also feels stupid at times, they are undodgeable especially if its supposed to be a jumpscare. You're just sitting there helplessly watching your character go through an 8 second animation as you take big unnecessary damage, it would be better if we can somehow mash a certain button to push the enemy away.

Enemy types, having 5 or more type of enemy to fight is great and all, it reduces the "repetitive" aspect of the game. However, some enemies are actually annoying to deal with. Aside from the fact that they are tanky, [spoiler] one would spit goo, and hold you down in place while the other enemy stabs you in the back. All of this happening in one tight space.[/spoiler] Other than that, common enemy placement doesn't make sense for me, at least, story-wise. SH2 has less enemy variety, however, common enemies are placed where they are supposed to be and everything feels in place. SHf on the other hand, feels like they're just throwing enemies at you to slow you down.

[h2]STORY:[/h2]
[spoiler]Its just a generic highschool girl story made scary and complicated.[/spoiler] The story felt like it was dumbed down. What made the previous Silent Hill stories wonderful is that they relied on "player interpretation", while SHf just straight-up told the entire story and left nothing for the player to think about. There's no mystery.

[h2]POSITIVES:[/h2]
This is not a rant but a critic take on SHf. Though, I felt like most of what I've written are focused on the negative aspect of the game, here's what I actually found interesting and good about the game.

Silent Hill set on Japan is a breath of fresh air. I love the new scenery far from the usual "small and abandoned american town". The rotten flesh and flowers that blooms to symbolize corruption instead of the usual rust and decay feels right for the story. Not only did it fit, it worked aesthetically wonderful.

Addition of Omamori items were interesting. It's not something we usually find in a horror game, but it's nice to have for combat and survival.

Boss fights are great especially the few at the end. Their patterns are readable which makes boss fights actually fun. Made me feel like I'm playing a souls game.

SH2R's combat feels modern and refreshed, SHf retained that and added new mechanics which makes it fun.

[h2]TLDR:[/h2]
I don't regret buying it, I love Silent Hill games, and I love that Konami is now pouring their love at the Silent Hill franchise again after neglecting it for so long. But this one, specifically, is not for me. The game started strong, but fell apart hard along the way.

The only valid defense behind the repetitive nature in this game is that it thematically fits what the protagonist is struggling with. But again, this doesn't fully justify the game forcing you to play it 3-4 excruciating times to understand the entire story and characters.
